C. sinensis is widely used in skin care preparations for its peculiar catechines having significant antioxidant, anti-inflammatory and UV-protection activities. Moreover, tea polyphenols, i.e. (–)-epicatechin 3- O-gallate, (–)-gallocatechin 3- O-gallate, and (–)-epigallocatechin 3- O-gallate (EGCG) are known to possess tyrosinase inhibitory potential
24 .
